According to the U.S. Statistical Abstract, there are approximately 4,678,000
people in 2004 (Table 694 in the 2007 edition) that are living below the poverty line
and that are both foreign born and are not United States citizens. According to
the Income, Poverty, and Health Insurance Coverage in the United States: 2004,
21.6% of foreign born, non-citizen population has money income below the
poverty line and the median income for this group is $34,497 - significantly below
the median for foreign-born householders who are citizens ($39,421), native
households ($45,319) and naturalized citizens ($46,233).

In this proposed regulation, the increases in fees for permanent residency by
178% to $905 and naturalization by 80% to $595 puts an excessive and unfair
economic burden on a disadvantaged population. It will serve as a disincentive for
immigrants to come to our country and for those already here, it will serve as an
obstacle to changing their status.

The U.S. Congress and the USCIS must find ways to fund immigrant services so
that they are available and are affordable to those that need them. Excessive fees
coupled with a focus on law enforcement acts to criminalize and create untold
hardships for immigrants and their families. We need policies that support
immigrant families, that recognizes the important role they play in our national
economy and that work to incorporate immigrants as full members of our
communities. Anything less is both a disservice to immigrants and a disservice to
ourselves.

http://www.census.gov/prod/2005pubs/p60-229.pdf
